channel.title: WHATWG-relevant MDN issues
channel.description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG

item.title: [html] Issue with "Window.localStorage": Safari deletes after 7 days unvisited
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/localStorage

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page suggests that localStorage persists forever.

But then WebKit made this March 2020 announcement https://webkit.org/blog/10218/full-third-party-cookie-blocking-and-more/ that they will automatically clear a domain's localStorage after 7 days where the browser is opened but the domain is not visited.

Specific section or headline?

the stored data is saved across browser sessions.

except that while localStorage data has no expiration time

What did you expect to see?

A clarification note about Apple's stated policy of automatically deleting a domains localStorage if not visited for 7 days when Safari is opened.

Some commentary on this issue:

  • https://www.theregister.com/2020/03/26/apple_relax_were_not_totally/
  • https://ar.al/2020/03/25/apple-just-killed-offline-web-apps-while-purporting-to-protect-your-privacy-why-thats-a-bad-thing-and-why-you-should-care/
  • https://andregarzia.com/2020/03/private-client-side-only-pwas-are-hard-but-now-apple-made-them-impossible.html

These all respond to the announcement, but I'm having trouble finding recent documentation about this issue on MDN or elsewhere.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Not yet. Requires at least 7 days to test, but I can write something up if there's interest.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/window/localstorage
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/localStorage
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/window/localstorage/index.html
  • Last commit: 6702960
  • Document last modified: 2021-08-21T21:04:34.000Z

item.title: [html, webgl1, dom, selection-api] [Markdown] [Web/API] Fix live samples which use heading IDs that are not derived from heading text
item.content:encoded:
Part of #7898.

In MDN live samples pass an ID to identify where Yari should look for the code blocks to include. This ID should always be a heading ID, in Markdown. Also in Markdown, the heading ID is always derived from the heading text - it doesn't have an independent existence.

But in HTML the heading ID does have an independent existence, so can be different from the one that would be generated from the heading text. If a heading has such an ID in our HTML, and a live sample uses it, then that live sample will break when we convert to Markdown.

I believe that this issue affects the following pages:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvas_api/tutorial/applying_styles_and_colors
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvas_api/tutorial/compositing
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/css_object_model/using_dynamic_styling_information
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/css_painting_api/guide
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/datatransferitemlist
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/datatransferitemlist/length
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document_object_model/introduction
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document_object_model/traversing_an_html_table_with_javascript_and_dom_interfaces
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document_object_model/whitespace
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/element/queryselector
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventtarget/addeventlistener
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/globaleventhandlers/onselectionchange
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/htmlelement/focus
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/navigator/canshare
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/settimeout
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/webglrenderingcontext

item.title: [html] Issue with "WorkerGlobalScope.importScripts()": (confucing description of parameters)
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

These paths are relative to html document base URL.

That's confusing cause some people may think that these are the only options available to pass into importScripts

What did you expect to see?

Did you test this? If so, how?

Tested. Uploaded on different hosts and tried to run – everything worked

The main FormData could also mention this event,.

item.title: [html, cssom-view-1, dom, uievents, FileAPI, WebIDL-1, pointerlock-2] Remove alert() from live samples
item.content:encoded:
window.alert() doesn't work cross-origin in Chrome any more, meaning that any of our live samples that rely on alert() are now broken.

See also #7553.

This is (I think) all the live samples in Web/API that use alert() in a live sample:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/attr/localname
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/canvasrenderingcontext2d/addhitregion
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/document/querycommandstate
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/domexception/domexception
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventlistener
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/eventtarget/addeventlistener
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/file/name
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/keyboardevent/metakey
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/mouseevent
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/notifications_api/using_the_notifications_api
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/find
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/windoworworkerglobalscope/settimeout (fixed in #7560)

(I might have missed some).

We should replace all of these with some alternative. A common alternative is to write the output into an element in the example's document.

item.title: [html] Issue with "<form>": describe running javascript on submit: `onsubmit` and javascript pseudo-protocol
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/form

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I have been reading Stack Overflow for solutions to have a form run run javascript without refreshing the page. This is achieved by returning a javascript function in onsubmit, then the javascript function has to return false? https://stackoverflow.com/a/16262814

Also there is a method to do action="javascript:function()" that probably should be documented.

There is also the solutions here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12694984/make-form-run-a-javascript-function?noredirect=1&lq=1

Specific section or headline?

Attributes?

item.title: [html] Content bug: Mention that the `formdata` event allows modifying the form payload
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FormDataEvent
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FormData/Using_FormData_Objects#using_a_formdata_event

What is the problem?

The descriptions of the formdata event mention it as a way to "quickly" obtain a FormData object with the same form entries that are being submitted. It fails to mention that modifications to the obtained FormData object from inside the event listener will affect the submitted form payload.

What did you expect to see?

Text mentioning that it's possible to modify the form payload in this way.

Did you test this? If so, how?

<form id="form" action="" method="GET">
<p><input type="submit"></p>
</form>

<script>
  document.getElementById("form").addEventListener("formdata", (evt) => {
    evt.formData.append("a", "b");
  });
</script>

If the HTML above is served at, say, http://example.com/index.html, clicking the submit button in browsers that support the formdata event will navigate to http://example.com/index.html?a=b rather than to http://example.com/index.html?.

item.title: [html, web-locks] Avoiding duplication/confusion between Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator
item.content:encoded:
mdn/browser-compat-data#9125 is a long discussion about the peculiar cases of Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator, which are the only APIs on the web platform where distinct interfaces are used to represent the "same" thing in window and worker contexts.

For example, navigator.userAgent is available in both window and worker contexts, but navigator itself is a different kind of object. (This difference rarely matters in practice.)

BCD will follow the structure of specs/implementations, but on MDN there's duplication that might be possible to avoid. These pairs of pages and their subpages should be considered for merging or cross-linking:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Location + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerLocation

For location it's probably best to keep them separate since the worker variant is read-only. But navigator it's hard to see the usefulness of splits like this:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/locks
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/locks

item.title: [html] CustomElementRegistry needs updating
item.content:encoded:
I've been documenting ElementInternals, in the process of this I think that the documentation we have for custom elements may need some updating. In particular I noticed that https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CustomElementRegistry includes no information about the disable internals, or disable shadow booleans.

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#concept-custom-element-definition-disable-internals

I think it would probably be worth someone taking a look at this content and seeing what else needs updating.

Once updated it would be good to link this to the information about attachInternals in /Web/API/Element/attachInternals

item.title: [console] Issue with "console", how does number formatting work? Number formatting doesn't work on Chrome.
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The section "Using string substitutions" mentions that %i and %d allow number formatting, and gives a single example, but this example does not fully explain how this is used. In addition to that, in my testing, it appears that Chrome ignores the formatting and prints out the number with %i, %d, and %f.

Specific section or headline?

Under "Using string substitutions" and under "Browser Compatibility"

What did you expect to see?

I expected to see either a description, or a link to a page with a description, on how one may use the number formatting. It isn't quite straightforward from what is written here. In addition to this, I expected to see Browser Compatibility make some mention that the formatting is ignored on Chrome.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested out number formatting, and (at least on chrome) the logging (log, info, warn, and error) appears to ignore number formatting. The "Browser Compatibility" section has no mention of this substitution string formatting issue.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/console
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/console/index.html
  • Last commit: cbca120
  • Document last modified: 2021-06-28T01:25:18.000Z

item.title: [html] Issue with "<input>: The Input (Form Input) element": Incorrect or ambiguous description of step attribute
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The document states that "date/time" input types use step scale factor of 1000, and that step default is 60 (seconds):

For the date/time input types, step is expressed in seconds, with the default step being 60 seconds. The step scale factor is 1000 (which converts the seconds to milliseconds, as used in other algorithms).

Where "date/time" types are, as far as I understand, any types that are related to date and/or time, not just datetime.

But for week and month, which I consider as "date" types, it's not true.

For type=date:

The step attribute is expressed in weeks. The step scale factor is 604,800,000 (which converts the weeks to milliseconds, as used in the other algorithms). The default step is 1 week. The default step base is −259,200,000 (the start of week 1970-W01).

For type=month:

The step attribute is expressed in months. The step scale factor is 1 (there is no conversion needed as the algorithms use months). The default step is 1 month.

Even the type=date is different:

The step attribute is expressed in days. The step scale factor is 86,400,000 (which converts the days to milliseconds, as used in the other algorithms). The default step is 1 day.

The only type that matches it is type=datetime-local.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/Input#htmlattrdefstep

What did you expect to see?

Either correct descriptions of each type's default values, or don't mention default values at all. Instead, add links pointing to each type's step descriptions instead, e.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input/week#attr-step and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input/month#attr-step

Did you test this? If so, how?

No.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/html/element/input
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/html/element/input/index.html
  • Last commit: 8d28de3
  • Document last modified: 2021-06-02T17:52:41.000Z

item.title: [html] WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope call information on Window and WorkerGlobalScope is out of date
item.content:encoded:
Should https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerGlobalScope just reference WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope instead of including everything in the Properties implemented from elsewhere section?
Currently both those pages don't mention crossOriginIsolated and say origin "does not yet appear to be implemented in any browser" even though https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope says it was implemented in Chrome 59 and Firefox 54.

item.title: [dom] Event.composedPath() refers to nonexistent example
item.content:encoded:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/composedPath says:

In our composed-composed-path example (see it live), we define two trivial custom elements, and ...

...but "(see it live)" doesn't link to anything. I couldn't see anything likely in https://github.com/mdn/dom-examples/, maybe it's somewhere else, or maybe it's just gone?

item.title: [html] Issue with "WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope.clearTimeout()": (Can failure be detected?)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/clearTimeout

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says nothing about what happens if clearTimeout is too late, and fails to deactivate a setTimeout operation. In fact, it implies that failure to clear cannot be detected.

Specific section or headline?

Notes

What did you expect to see?

Usually when clearTimeout is issued, the setTimeout function is still in progress. However, there are race conditions where setTimeout is ending just as clearTimeout is issued. If setTimeout has just ended, but not yet been detected or handled, one may want clearTimeout to detect this as an error, but the MDN documentation is unclear as to whether this is possible or not. This can be an important error condition during asynchronous operations where setTimeout is used. Data loss or worse can result if we rely on clearTimeout to prevent a timeout in the rare case when the timeout has just happened, since this case cannot be detected either before or after the call to clearTimeout.

Of course, we can detect that setTimeout resolved much later, and so can eventually know that a call to clearTimeout failed, but only if we know to test for this unusual case. Either way, the documentation could be more helpful.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Asynchronous race conditions hurt my head, and can be very rare, and so I don't know how to test for them.

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/windoworworkerglobalscope/cleartimeout
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/clearTimeout
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/windoworworkerglobalscope/cleartimeout/index.html
  • Last commit: 94c536f
  • Document last modified: 2021-05-31T17:13:02.000Z

item.title: [fetch] Issue with "WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope.fetch()": Incomplete description for `TypeError`
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In the page about the fetch method, I think the description of the TypeError exception is incomplete.

At https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch#exceptions under TypeError

The description says:

The specified URL string includes user credentials. This information should instead be provided using an Authorization header.

Specific section or headline?

At https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch#exceptions under TypeError

Corresponding to these source lines on github fetch/index.html#L149-L151

What did you expect to see?

I think that it would be useful to mention that fetch can reject with a TypeError due to a ill-formed request or a network error.

If I am reading it correctly, it is part of the spec https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#fetch-method:

at step 2

Let requestObject be the result of invoking the initial value of Request as constructor with input and init as arguments. If this throws an exception, reject p with it and return p.

and 12.3

If response is a network error, then reject p with a TypeError and terminate these substeps.

Maybe something along these lines could work:

TypeError
    There are several reason fetch can be interrupted with a `TypeError`:
    - it was not possible to build a `Request` object with the provided parameters (e.g. malformed url)
    - the request was interrupted due to a network error 
    - ... other reasons for fetch to reject with TypeError ...

Did you test this? If so, how?

In the developer console of Microsoft Edge Version 91.0.864.37 (Official build) (64-bit)

I made a fetch request to a localhost on a closed port and checked the rejection error

fetch("http://localhost:8080").catch(err => console.log(err));

With result

> TypeError: Failed to fetch

Then I made a fetch request to a malformed url

fetch("k2143rjhttp://localhost:9999/hello").catch(err => console.log(err))

With result

> TypeError: Failed to fetch
MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/windoworworkerglobalscope/fetch
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/windoworworkerglobalscope/fetch/index.html
  • Last commit: 94c536f
  • Document last modified: 2021-05-31T17:13:02.000Z

item.title: [html, selectors-4] Issue with ":target" and Web Components
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:target

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Let's assume you have this Web Component:

let template = `
	<div>
		<a href="#message">Make the message red</a>
		<h2 id="message">Message in a bottle</h2>
	</div>
	<style>
		#message:target {
			color: red;
		}
	</style>
`;

customElements.define('my-component', class myElement extends HTMLElement {
	constructor() {
		super();
		let shadowRoot = this.attachShadow({ mode: 'open' });
		shadowRoot.innerHTML = template;
	}
});

This code fails to work because the event :target is missing in the root of the shadow.

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

I expected that :target would work inside the web components.
I expect the message to run red when clicking on the link.

Did you test this? If so, how?

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/css/_colon_target
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:target
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/css/_colon_target/index.html
  • Last commit: f4fb4c2
  • Document last modified: 2021-03-15T17:55:56.000Z

item.title: [html, cssom-view-1] Window.open() needs an overhaul
item.content:encoded: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/open is long, rambling, and very out of date. It needs a brave person to work out what a page on this feature should contain in 2021.

item.title: [html] Issue with "HTMLSlotElement.assignedNodes()": misleading phrasing
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLSlotElement/assignedNodes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The article states that, if no assigned nodes are found, the function returns the slot's fallback content.

I believe that is only true if the options parameter is passed the value {flatten: true}. I think the article doesn't make that clear enough.

Specific section or headline?

At the very beginning of the article:

The assignedNodes() property of the HTMLSlotElement interface returns a sequence of the nodes assigned to this slot, and if the flatten option is set to true, the assigned nodes of any other slots that are descendants of this slot. If no assigned nodes are found, it returns the slot's fallback content.

Same problem in these pages, which basically repeat that paragraph:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLSlotElement/assignedElements
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLSlotElement

What did you expect to see?

I think the following changes would make it clearer that the section I highlighted above only applies if flatten is set to true:

The assignedNodes() property of the HTMLSlotElement interface returns a sequence of the nodes assigned to this slot.

If the flatten option is set to true, it returns a sequence of the assigned nodes of any other slots that are descendants of this slot, and if no assigned nodes are found, it returns the slot's fallback content.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Same results in Firefox and Chrome:

The <button> is part of the slot's fallback content and is only returned with {flatten: true}.

The spec seems to confirm that:

MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/htmlslotelement/assignednodes
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLSlotElement/assignedNodes
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/htmlslotelement/assignednodes/index.html
  • Last commit: 11c96e4
  • Document last modified: 2021-03-30T03:01:23.000Z

item.title: [orientation-event, compat] Content bug: Improve device/screen orientation event doc
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

A number of docs related to device orientation

Orientation and motion data explained

  • Still marked as draft
  • Does not cover DeviceMotion frame.
  • Explains only the absolute frame, not the relative frame.

Web APIs > Detecting device orientation

  • needs better linking to above doc.

  • Window.ondeviceorientationabsolute - corresponding docs missing. Looks like this is absolute-only version of orientation relative to earth frame, based on compass.

  • Window.deviceorientation_event and Window.ondeviceorientation

    • Marked experimental, but looks like the main API
    • Documented as relative to earth frame, but has absolute and relative value. Various docs indicate it is not standardised and some systems do relative, some absolute. Not clear what relative "means". So basically need to find out what relative means and what systems support what behaviour.

  • Window.orientationchange (also the event). This is the angle relative to the natural device orientation of the screen. So relative to the deviceorientation.

    • Marked as deprecated, but not clear what should be used?
    • There is also Screen.onorientationchange that is also deprecated and FF only.

  • CSS Object Model (CSSOM) > Managing screen orientation - this looks OK but refers to deprecated Screen.onorientationchange

Other relevant docs:

  • Window.devicemotion_event (and friends)
  • Google doc on topic
    Anyway,
  • Chrome 50 info on change that confuses me
  • Pretty cool tute

item.title: [html] Issue with "CanvasRenderingContext2D.drawImage()": How to omit sWidth or sHeight?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/drawImage

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The documentation says you can omit either sHeight or sWidth. The documentation also says that the other function definitions do not contain these parameters. Setting these parameters to null or undefined does not seem to work. How can these params be omited?

MDN Content page report details

Specific page section or heading?

The link to resize under https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLVideoElement/videoHeight#about_intrinsic_width_and_height and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLVideoElement/videoHeight#example is broken. It may not exist.

Link to resize is broken. It may not exist. See conversation on this PR: #4059 (comment)

What did you expect to see?

(1) Working resize link or (2) remove resize link if does not exist.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Link to resize is red as it's broken.

More detailed explanation

item.title: [html] Issue with "WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope.btoa()": Missing snippet for Unicode chars as found on DE page
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/btoa

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

EN page is missing really helpful function from the DE page

Specific section or headline?

This snippet, contributed by Johan Sundström for handling Unicode characters was provided on the DE page:

function utf8_to_b64(str) {
    return window.btoa(unescape(encodeURIComponent(str)));
}

function b64_to_utf8(str) {
    return decodeURIComponent(escape(window.atob(str)));
}

// Usage:
utf8_to_b64('✓ à la mode'); // JTI1dTI3MTMlMjUyMCUyNUUwJTI1MjBsYSUyNTIwbW9kZQ==
b64_to_utf8('JTI1dTI3MTMlMjUyMCUyNUUwJTI1MjBsYSUyNTIwbW9kZQ=='); // "✓ à la mode"

utf8_to_b64('I \u2661 Unicode!'); // SSUyNTIwJTI1dTI2NjElMjUyMFVuaWNvZGUlMjUyMQ==
b64_to_utf8('SSUyNTIwJTI1dTI2NjElMjUyMFVuaWNvZGUlMjUyMQ=='); // "I ♡ Unicode!"

When viewing the page in ENglish, that's no where to be found.
Adding this snippet to both EN and other languages will definitely help everyone looking into this function.

What did you expect to see?

Function as mentioned above on DE page

Did you test this? If so, how?

Changed language of page to a few different ones (Polish has this snippet) – to help all chars of the world, would be great to add to page for all languges.

item.title: [fetch] Content suggestion: Document Headers.forEach()
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

The Headers.forEach( ) is missing documentation https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Headers

Why is it important or useful?

The callback seems to receive value, key instead of key, value. The programmer might or might not get this right without documentation. We need one page explaining the type of the forEach method. I imagine some page for a similar method could be used as a starting point. Might still take an hour or two to verify that this method follows te same behaviour. Adding this would reduce the amount of mistakes related to expecting the reversed callback argument order.

item.title: [dom, web-bluetooth] Content bug: linking macros to Boolean shouldn't be {{domxref}}
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

127 pages (mainly in the Web API references).

For example:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMTokenList/contains
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Bluetooth/requestDevice
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Firefox/Releases/45

Specific page section or heading?

Various sections in various reference pages.

What is the problem?

{{domxref("Boolean")}} is used in a lot of pages.
However I thought it should be {{jsxref("Boolean")}} because Boolean isn't an interface of Web API and actually the {{domxref("Boolean")}} is redirected to the JavaScript reference.

This looks no problem due to redirecting, but it produces broken link in translation versions.

However {{jsxref("Boolean")}} is also incorrect because many of Web APIs use boolean primitive, not a Boolean object.

What did you expect to see?

{{jsxref("Boolean")}}, or another way to show it is a boolean primitive correctly.

Did you test this? If so, how?

item.title: [html] Issue with "HTMLFormElement: formdata event": The example code is bonkers
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLFormElement/formdata_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The 'formdata' event is being used to fire an ajax request.

// submit the data via XHR
var request = new XMLHttpRequest();
request.open("POST", "/formHandler");
request.send(data);

Specific section or headline?

Code under "Examples"

What did you expect to see?

formdata event is to be used as a hook by custom implementations of form elements to modify the form output (by mutating e.formData) before it's submitted/serialized, it is NOT a substitute of the submit event. I shudder to think that if the example code made into real code-bases then it will prevent adoption of valid usages of this event.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Why is it important or useful?

item.title: [html] Issue with "Document: drag event": removeChild seems superfluous - is a draggedElement moved in the dom tree?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/drag_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It is unclear to me how a dragged element is treated by the browser.
I would expect that deleting dragged.parentNode.removeChild would change the demo.
But it seem that dragging an element removes it from its current position in the dom tree.

Specific section or headline?

The fiddle demo contains these lines

      if ( event.target.className == "dropzone" ) {
          event.target.style.background = "";
          dragged.parentNode.removeChild( dragged );
          event.target.appendChild( dragged );
      }

What did you expect to see?

After commenting out dragged.parentNode.removeChild i would expect that there are two dragged-divs the one that was appended and the orignal one that was not removed.

      if ( event.target.className == "dropzone" ) {
          event.target.style.background = "";
          // dragged.parentNode.removeChild( dragged );
          event.target.appendChild( dragged );
      }

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yes i forked the demo on fiddle

item.title: [html] Issue with "Document: drag event": example behaves strange around text selection
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example behaves incorrectly in certain circumstances. This isn't exactly a critical bug, but people may inadvertently copy the example without realising it fails on edge-cases. Basically, it's possible to select the text inside the dive and drag that. I suppose in the dragstart event handler there should be a verification that the dragged element is the intended div and nothing else?

In firefox the text selection is clearly visible, but in Chrome there isn't such feedback.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/drag_event#examples

What did you expect to see?

Either the text is draggable, but not accepted by the dropzone, and/or the text is not selectable

Did you test this? If so, how?

firefox:

chrome:

item.title: [notifications] Notification
item.content:encoded:
The demo on

https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/notification/notification/index.html

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Notification/Notification

throws the following error;

The Notification permission may only be requested from inside a short running user-generated event handler.

Chromium on Android reports:

Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Notification': Illegal constructor. Use ServiceWorkerRegistration.showNotification() instead.

and ServiceWorkerRegistration.showNotification only works if google services is installed.

item.title: [html] Issue with "WebSocket.send()": Exceptions thrown listed is incorrect
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket/send

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In the Exceptions Thrown section, it says the INVALID_STATE_ERR exception is thrown when send is called while the connection is not OPEN. That is incorrect, as an exception is only called in the CONNECTING state; if CLOSING or CLOSED, send just discards the data. Refer to RFC: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/web-sockets.html#dom-websocket-send
Or run the following snippet in a browser console:

var ws = new WebSocket("wss://invalid-ws-url.com");
setTimeout(() => ws.send("Hello"), 5000);

Specific section or headline?

Exceptions thrown->INVALID_STATE_ERR

What did you expect to see?

Should say it only throws in the state is CONNECTING. Should probably mention in the description of the method that it doesn't do anything if the connection is already closed, and the onus is on the user to check the readyState before calling send.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Ran a snippet in the browser console:

var ws = new WebSocket("wss://invalid-ws-url.com");
setTimeout(() => ws.send("Hello"), 5000);
MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/websocket/send
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket/send
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/websocket/send/index.html
  • Last commit: f6f11d2
  • Document last modified: 2021-02-19T19:33:30.000Z

item.title: [dom] Document CharacterData
item.content:encoded:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CharacterData is incomplete. None of the sub pages exist but they should. CharacterData is a core DOM API that is well supported and that should have proper docs.

This came up in #2394 where I removed the weird NonDocumentTypeChildNode mixin, so don't worry about that anymore.

CharacterData is the parent interface for Text, ProcessingInstruction, and Comment nodes, so when creating the pages and example code, you probably want to show how to use CharacterData methods like appendData() with something concrete like https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Text nodes.

item.title: [dom] Browser Compatibility tables are unclear when support for an item has been removed
item.content:encoded:
This is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1417902 filed again for the new MDN setup.

The problem is clearly illustrated by things that were in EdgeHTML (Edge 12-18) but are not in new Chromium-based Edge 79+:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DocumentType#browser_compatibility

It looks as though support was in Edge 12-79, but it was in Edge 12-18.

cc @Elchi3 @ddbeck

item.title: [url] Issue with "URLSearchParams": should mention duplicate parameters and if conversion is lossless
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams

Questions which I came to the documentation for:

  1. How does URLSearchParams handle the same parameter appearing more than once, for example
for (const i of new URLSearchParams("?first=1&second=2&first=3")); { console.log(i) } // ["first", "1"] ["second", "2"] ["first", "3"]
new URLSearchParams("?first=1&second=2&first=3").get('first'); // "1"

Edit: nevermind, this second line is documented in .get() "Returns the first value", I was unsure about the first because I've seen a different javascript library return a list as the second item in each entry. I still think it would be good to mention this in the examples too.

  1. Does iterating over URLSearchParams preserve the order of the params or is it implemented with an unordered JavaScript dictionary?

it's implemented with a list of lists so order is preserved.

  1. Are round trip conversions lossless? How does it differentiate between params with and without an =?

No it's not lossless because ?param and ?param= both parse as having a value of "" instead of null for the former and "" for the latter, so they are both converted to ?param=

for (const i of new URLSearchParams("?first=&second")) { console.log(i) } // ["first", ""] ["second", ""]
String(new URLSearchParams("?first=&second")); // "first=&second="
MDN Content page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/urlsearchparams
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URLSearchParams
  • GitHub URL: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/master/files/en-us/web/api/urlsearchparams/index.html
  • Last commit: dad0283
  • Document last modified: 2020-12-21T19:02:54.000Z

item.title: [html] [Media] Enable AVIF support
item.content:encoded:
Acceptance criteria

    • The listed features are documented sufficiently on MDN
    • BCD is updated
    • Interactive example and data repos are updated if appropriate
    • The content has been reviewed as needed

Features to document

  1. AVIF. We don't really record compat-data for image formats as such, but you can find details of this at:
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Image_types
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Performance/Multimedia
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/img

So a few places to update information.

Related Gecko bugs

    • Enable AVIF support by default

For folks helping with Firefox-related documentation features — make sure above AC have been done, but also:

  • Set bugs to dev-doc-complete
  • Add entry to Firefox release notes if feature is enabled in release
  • Add entry to Firefox experimental features page if feature is not yet enabled in release

item.title: [html] requestAnimationFrame is also available in Dedicated Workers
item.content:encoded:
@chrisdavidmills commented on Mon Oct 05 2020

@Kaiido commented on Mon Oct 05 2020

Content Issue

  • Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

URLs of page you are seeing the problem on:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/cancelAnimationFrame

Details

requestAnimationFrame and cancelAnimationFrame used to be Window only methods, but it has recently been added to DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope too. https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/imagebitmap-and-animations.html#animationframeprovider

interface mixin AnimationFrameProvider {
  unsigned long requestAnimationFrame(FrameRequestCallback callback);
  undefined cancelAnimationFrame(unsigned long handle);
};
Window includes AnimationFrameProvider;
DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope includes AnimationFrameProvider;

I guess the page should now be Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/requestAnimationFrame, but I fear this would break any link to the current /Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame. So I'm not sure how it should get handled.

Also, compat-data should probably be updated (currently these methods are supported in Blink only).

item.title: [dom] https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCollection - Left column lists incorrect properties and methods.
item.content:encoded:
@parke commented on Fri Aug 07 2020

Request type

  • [] Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

Details

On the referenced page, the left "quick navigation" column incorrectly lists:

Properties
item

The correct list would be:

Properties
length

Methods
item()
namedItem()

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCollection

item.title: [fetch] Rationalize top-level Web API pages
item.content:encoded:
According to mdn/sprints#3327 we have ~1100 pages directly under Web/API.

I believe that every page directly under Web/API must be one of:

  1. an API overview page, e.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API
  2. an interface page, e.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request
  3. a dictionary page, e.g. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AesGcmParams

While it's hard to tell which pages are in group (1), a reasonable heuristic seems to be: if the title contains a space, the page is an API overview page. But that heuristic we have about 100 API overview pages, leaving about 1000 others.

As far as I know, all the others ought to be either interface pages or dictionary pages, so ought to be listed in GroupData.json. In fact, ~250 of these pages are not listed in GroupData.

Additionally, some interfaces/dictionaries appear under more than one group in GroupData. I believe that this should not be allowed.

So we should:

  • tag API overview pages, so we know exactly which ones they have
  • ensure all API overview pages have a corresponding entry in GroupData.json
  • tag all dictionary pages
  • ensure all dictionary pages are listed under an entry in GroupData.json
  • tag all interface pages
  • ensure all interface pages are listed under an entry in GroupData.json
  • relocate or delete any other pages that aren't in one of these three categories
  • remove any duplicate interface/dictionary entries from GroupData

item.title: [html] Disambiguate Exceptions Types and Exception Names Across MDN
item.content:encoded:
Request type

  • Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

Details

Some Exception sections on MDN don't make a distinction between error types and error names. For example, CustomElementRegistry.define() lists the following items under Exceptions

  • NotSupportedError
  • SyntaxError
  • TypeError

If you do console.log(typeof ExceptionName) on instances of these, you'll find that the type for NotSupportedError is DOMException. The name NotSupported is what's returned by DOMException.name. The remaining two are actually error types.

I would just correct the page I linked to except this appears to be a wide-spread problem on MDN that requires a standard approach.
